snippet: Malaysian authorities were struggling to interpret data showing what could be the lost Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 veering off course and hundreds of miles from its last known position.
abstract: Malaysian military admits that it recorded, but initially ignored, radar signals from the last known location of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, suggesting that plane may have turned away from its original course; data shows unidentified aircraft headed west out into Indian ocean, prompting officials to expand search area to take in 27,000 square nautical miles; military is now sharing data with American agencies.

byline.original: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and THOMAS FULLER
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong, Patrick Zuo from Beijing, and Eric Schmitt and Matthew L. Wald from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Malaysian authorities were struggling to interpret data showing what could be the lost Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 veering off course and hundreds of miles from its last known position.

headline.main: Signals on Radar Puzzle Officials in Hunt for Malaysian Jet
headline.print_headline: Signals on Radar Puzzle Officials in Hunt for Jet
